Award.AwardTitle: Evolutionary genetics of a cosmopolitan generalist herbivore
Award.AbstractNarration:
To counteract grazing by animal herbivores, plants use a large array of defenses that include the production of toxic compounds. In turn, herbivores exploit diverse strategies to overcome these plant defenses. As herbivores have profound impacts on natural plant communities, and are one of the major sources of crop loss in agriculture, understanding the genetic basis and strategies for how herbivores adapt to feed on plant hosts is of ecological and agricultural relevance. The objective of this research is to characterize the genetic underpinnings of the interaction between the two-spotted spider mite herbivore and different plant hosts. This mite species is well known as a generalist herbivore, meaning that it can feed on many plant species, including more than a hundred crop plants. The research will further our understanding of the extent to which given strains of generalist herbivores can persist equally well on diverse plant hosts, or alternatively may be specialized to more specific subsets of plant species. Furthermore, the research will characterize which genes and alleles, including ones that impact variation in gene expression regulation, are important for the life history of this generalist herbivore. Outcomes of the research will include specific insights into forces shaping genetic variation in generalist herbivores relevant to human welfare, and the work will more broadly inform studies in diverse organisms that aim to elucidate the genetic basis of adaptation to changing environments. The research will also train K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students.

To accomplish the research objectives, mite strains from diverse geographical locations and host plants will be collected. Using high-throughput DNA sequencing, the genomes of the strains will subsequently be determined to describe genetic variation. Molecular signatures of selection will then be assessed for genes associated with, for example, the metabolism of plant toxins. Complementing these studies of DNA variation, high-throughput transcriptome sequencing will also be performed to assess the possibility that variation in the regulation of these genes underlies establishment on different hosts. Finally, genetic crosses, followed by sequencing of resulting populations selected on different plant hosts, will be carried out to identify specific genes and alleles underlying host-plant adaptation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animal herbivores subsist by consuming plant tissue. To counteract grazing by herbivores, plants have many defenses, of which a major one is chemical compounds that are toxic to the animals that try to eat them. Herbivores must overcome these plant-produced toxins and other plant defenses to be successful. In agricultural and urban settings, herbivores often also encounter pesticides as well, which are synthetic toxins (also called xenobiotics), and adaptation to these compounds has been hypothesized to have a similar genetic basis. The molecular and genetic basis of how herbivores adapt to host plants and the environments they face has long attracted interest, as it impacts their populations and plants in natural settings, and herbivore damage is a major source of crop loss, impacting human welfare. For this project, we investigated the molecular and genetic mechanisms by which an herbivore can persist on and adapt to different host plants and toxins that it encounters. Our focal organism of study was the two-spotted spider mite (scientific name, Tetranychus urticae). This herbivore is a generalist, a term that means that it can use many different types of host plants for food. Because of this, it persists on diverse plants in natural settings, but also on many crop plants, where it can cause damage.

By sequencing the genomes of many spider mite strains, we found substantial genetic differences in expanded gene families, including for genes involved in smell and taste, and for genes implicated in other animals as involved in breaking down toxic compounds. In particular, for the latter, we found that genes encoding proteins called cytochrome P450 monooxygenases (CYPs) were highly copy number variable between strains (in other words, some stains had more copies of the genes than others, which is associated with higher levels of RNA that encodes proteins). CYP proteins have known roles in breaking down toxic compounds. This genomic work, combined with prior studies from other organisms that have suggested that expanded and variable genes are involved in adaptation, strongly suggests that genes in these two families are involved in the major challenge spider mites face, adapting to novel host plants and xenobiotics. However, we also identified other expanded and copy variable gene families, suggesting that other genes are also important in these processes. Following up on this work, we adapted a genetic method known as bulk segregant analysis (BSA) mapping to study host plant and xenobiotic adaptation in long-term experimental populations of spider mites. As assessed with genes known to cause phenotypes in spider mites, the experimental designs and the BSA analysis approaches of our studies were successful in genetically mapping traits (that is, establishing which genomic regions are responsible for phenotypes). Turning these advances to the question of spider mite adaptation to host plants and toxic compounds, we identified small genomic regions containing genes including copy variable CYPs, a gene that makes a protein required for CYP activity, and in one case a gene that may regulate other genes (like CYPs) that can detoxify harmful compounds. A key outcome of our project is therefore an understanding of the types of genes that likely underlie the ability of generalist herbivores to persist on so many host plants. Finally, our studies suggest that while genetic variants in a few genes can allow adaptation to xenobiotics, adaptation to host plants (which have multiple chemicals as well as other defenses) is more complex.

Our project developed many resources for the scientific community studying herbivores, as well as for the public. The sequences of strains we examined are an important and public resource for the community of scientists working with ecologically and agriculturally important spider mites. Further, in accomplishing the projects aims, we improved the spider mite genome assembly, and its annotation, an important accomplishment in making spider mites a model for the study of herbivore-plant interactions. More generally, the project trained multiple undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. This included training in genomic and statistical methods, a recognized growth area in the biological sciences. More generally, research findings were incorporated into classroom and outreach presentations, reaching both K-12 and undergraduate students. Finally, materials on herbivore-plant interactions were developed in collaboration with the Genetic Science Learning Center of the University of Utah, and were made available for view by students, educators, and the public via the Learn.Genetics online educational resource.
